books.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 1

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 1:1
verses.text: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 1:2
verses.text: It is laid down at the outset that the customs of the holy life of the Church should be referred to the chief good of man, that is, God.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 1:3
verses.text: We must seek after God with supreme affection; and this doctrine is supported in the Catholic Church by the authority of both Testaments.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 1:4
verses.text: The four virtues get their names from different forms of this love.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 1:5
verses.text: Then follow the duties of love to our neighbor.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 1:6
verses.text: In the Catholic Church we find examples of continence and of true Christian conduct.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 2

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 2:1
verses.text: Chapter I.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 2:2
verses.text: —How the Pretensions of the Manich aeans are to Be Refuted.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 2:3
verses.text: Two Manich aean Falsehoods.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 2:4
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 2:5
verses.text: Enough, probably, has been done in our other books  in the way of answering the ignorant and profane attacks which the Manich aeans make on the law, which is called the Old Testament, in a spirit of vainglorious boasting, and with the approval of the uninstructed.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 2:6
verses.text: Here, too, I may shortly touch upon the subject.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 2:7
verses.text: For every one with average intelligence can easily see that the explanation of the Scriptures should be sought for from those who are the professed teachers of the Scriptures; and that it may happen, and indeed always happens, that many things seem absurd to the ignorant, which, when they are explained by the learned, appear all the more excellent, and are received in the explanation with the greater pleasure on account of the obstructions which made it difficult to reach the meaning.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 2:8
verses.text: This commonly happens as regards the holy books of the Old Testament, if only the man who meets with difficulties applies to a pious teacher, and not to a profane critic, and if he begins his inquiries from a desire to find truth, and not in rash opposition.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 2:9
verses.text: And should the inquirer meet with some, whether bishops or presbyters, or any officials or ministers of the Catholic Church, who either avoid in all cases opening up mysteries, or, content with simple faith, have no desire for more recondite knowledge, he must not despair of finding the knowledge of the truth in a case where neither are all able to teach to whom the inquiry is addressed, nor are all inquirers worthy of learning the truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 2:10
verses.text: Diligence and piety are both necessary: on the one hand, we must have knowledge to find truth, and, on the other hand, we must deserve to get the knowledge.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 2:11
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 2:12
verses.text: But as the Manich aeans have two tricks for catching the unwary, so as to make them take them as teachers,—one, that of finding fault with the Scriptures, which they either misunderstand or wish to be misunderstood, the other, that of making a show of chastity and of notable abstinence,—this book shall contain our doctrine of life and morals according to Catholic teaching, and will perhaps make it appear how easy it is to pretend to virtue, and how difficult to possess virtue.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 2:13
verses.text: I will refrain, if I can, from attacking their weak points, which I know well, with the violence with which they attack what they know nothing of; for I wish them, if possible, to be cured rather than conquered.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 2:14
verses.text: And I will quote such testimonies from the Scriptures as they are bound to believe, for they shall be from the New Testament; and even from this I will take none of the passages which the Manich aeans when hard pressed are accustomed to call spurious, but passages which they are obliged to acknowledge and approve.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 2:15
verses.text: And for every testimony from apostolic teaching I will bring a similar statement from the Old Testament, that if they ever become willing to wake up from their persistent dreams, and to rise towards the light of Christian faith, they may discover both how far from being Christian is the life which they profess, and how truly Christian is the Scripture which they cavil at.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 3

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 3:1
verses.text: Chapter 2 —He Begins with Arguments, in Compliance with the Mistaken Method of the Manich aeans.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 3:2
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 3:3
verses.text: Where, then, shall I begin? With authority, or with reasoning? In the order of nature, when we learn anything, authority precedes reasoning.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 3:4
verses.text: For a reason may seem weak, when, after it is given, it requires authority to confirm it.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 3:5
verses.text: But because the minds of men are obscured by familiarity with darkness, which covers them in the night of sins and evil habits, and cannot perceive in a way suitable to the clearness and purity of reason, there is most wholesome provision for bringing the dazzled eye into the light of truth under the congenial shade of authority.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 3:6
verses.text: But since we have to do with people who are perverse in all their thoughts and words and actions, and who insist on nothing more than on beginning with argument, I will, as a concession to them, take what I think a wrong method in discussion.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 3:7
verses.text: For I like to imitate, as far as I can, the gentleness of my Lord Jesus Christ, who took on Himself the evil of death itself, wishing to free us from it.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 4

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 4:1
verses.text: Chapter 3 —Happiness is in the Enjoyment of Man's Chief Good.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 4:2
verses.text: Two Conditions of the Chief Good: 1st, Nothing is Better Than It; 2d, It Cannot Be Lost Against the Will.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 4:3
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 4:4
verses.text: How then, according to reason, ought man to live? We all certainly desire to live happily; and there is no human being but assents to this statement almost before it is made.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 4:5
verses.text: But the title happy cannot, in my opinion, belong either to him who has not what he loves, whatever it may be, or to him who has what he loves if it is hurtful or to him who does not love what he has, although it is good in perfection.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 4:6
verses.text: For one who seeks what he cannot obtain suffers torture, and one who has got what is not desirable is cheated, and one who does not seek for what is worth seeking for is diseased.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 4:7
verses.text: Now in all these cases the mind cannot but be unhappy, and happiness and unhappiness cannot reside at the same time in one man; so in none of these cases can the man be happy.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 4:8
verses.text: I find, then, a fourth case, where the happy life exists,—when that which is man's chief good is both loved and possessed.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 4:9
verses.text: For what do we call enjoyment but having at hand the objects of love? And no one can be happy who does not enjoy what is man's chief good, nor is there any one who enjoys this who is not happy.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 4:10
verses.text: We must then have at hand our chief good, if we think of living happily.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 4:11
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 4:12
verses.text: We must now inquire what is man's chief good, which of course cannot be anything inferior to man himself.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 4:13
verses.text: For whoever follows after what is inferior to himself, becomes himself inferior.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 4:14
verses.text: But every man is bound to follow what is best.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 4:15
verses.text: Wherefore man's chief good is not inferior to man.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 4:16
verses.text: Is it then something similar to man himself? It must be so, if there is nothing above man which he is capable of enjoying.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 4:17
verses.text: But if we find something which is both superior to man, and can be possessed by the man who loves it, who can doubt that in seeking for happiness man should endeavor to reach that which is more excellent than the being who makes the endeavor.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 4:18
verses.text: For if happiness consists in the enjoyment of a good than which there is nothing better, which we call the chief good, how can a man be properly called happy who has not yet attained to his chief good? or how can that be the chief good beyond which something better remains for us to arrive at? Such, then, being the chief good, it must be something which cannot be lost against the will.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 4:19
verses.text: For no one can feel confident regarding a good which he knows can be taken from him, although he wishes to keep and cherish it.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 4:20
verses.text: But if a man feels no confidence regarding the good which he enjoys, how can he be happy while in such fear of losing it?.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 5

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 5:1
verses.text: Chapter 4 —Man—What?  6.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 5:2
verses.text: Let us then see what is better than man.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 5:3
verses.text: This must necessarily be hard to find, unless we first ask and examine what man is.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 5:4
verses.text: I am not now called upon to give a definition of man.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 5:5
verses.text: The question here seems to me to be,—since almost all agree, or at least, which is enough, those I have now to do with are of the same opinion with me, that we are made up of soul and body,—What is man? Is he both of these? or is he the body only, or the soul only? For although the things are two, soul and body, and although neither without the other could be called man (for the body would not be man without the soul, nor again would the soul be man if there were not a body animated by it), still it is possible that one of these may be held to be man, and may be called so.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 5:6
verses.text: What then do we call man? Is he soul and body, as in a double harness, or like a centaur? Or do we mean the body only, as being in the service of the soul which rules it, as the word lamp denotes not the light and the case together, but only the case, yet it is on account of the light that it is so called? Or do we mean only the mind, and that on account of the body which it rules, as horseman means not the man and the horse, but the man only, and that as employed in ruling the horse? This dispute is not easy to settle; or, if the proof is plain, the statement requires time.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 5:7
verses.text: This is an expenditure of time and strength which we need not incur.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 5:8
verses.text: For whether the name man belongs to both, or only to the soul, the chief good of man is not the chief good of the body; but what is the chief good either of both soul and body, or of the soul only, that is man's chief good.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 6

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 6:1
verses.text: Chapter 5 —Man's Chief Good is Not the Chief Good of the Body Only, But the Chief Good of the Soul.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 6:2
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 6:3
verses.text: Now if we ask what is the chief good of the body, reason obliges us to admit that it is that by means of which the body comes to be in its best state.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 6:4
verses.text: But of all the things which invigorate the body, there is nothing better or greater than the soul.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 6:5
verses.text: The chief good of the body, then, is not bodily pleasure, not absence of pain, not strength, not beauty, not swiftness, or whatever else is usually reckoned among the goods of the body, but simply the soul.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 6:6
verses.text: For all the things mentioned the soul supplies to the body by its presence, and, what is above them all, life.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 6:7
verses.text: Hence I conclude that the soul is not the chief good of man, whether we give the name of man to soul and body together, or to the soul alone.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 6:8
verses.text: For as according to reason, the chief good of the body is that which is better than the body, and from which the body receives vigor and life, so whether the soul itself is man, or soul and body both, we must discover whether there is anything which goes before the soul itself, in following which the soul comes to the perfection of good of which it is capable in its own kind.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 6:9
verses.text: If such a thing can be found, all uncertainty must be at an end, and we must pronounce this to be really and truly the chief good of man.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 6:10
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 6:11
verses.text: If, again, the body is man, it must be admitted that the soul is the chief good of man.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 6:12
verses.text: But clearly, when we treat of morals,—when we inquire what manner of life must be held in order to obtain happiness,—it is not the body to which the precepts are addressed, it is not bodily discipline which we discuss.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 6:13
verses.text: In short, the observance of good customs belongs to that part of us which inquires and learns, which are the prerogatives of the soul; so, when we speak of attaining to virtue, the question does not regard the body.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 6:14
verses.text: But if it follows, as it does, that the body which is ruled over by a soul possessed of virtue is ruled both better and more honorably, and is in its greatest perfection in consequence of the perfection of the soul which rightfully governs it, that which gives perfection to the soul will be man's chief good, though we call the body man.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 6:15
verses.text: For if my coachman, in obedience to me, feeds and drives the horses he has charge of in the most satisfactory manner, himself enjoying the more of my bounty in proportion to his good conduct, can any one deny that the good condition of the horses, as well as that of the coachman, is due to me? So the question seems to me to be not, whether soul and body is man, or the soul only, or the body only, but what gives perfection to the soul; for when this is obtained, a man cannot but be either perfect, or at least much better than in the absence of this one thing.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 7

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 7:1
verses.text: Chapter 6 —Virtue Gives Perfection to the Soul; The Soul Obtains Virtue by Following God; Following God is the Happy Life.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 7:2
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 7:3
verses.text: No one will question that virtue gives perfection to the soul.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 7:4
verses.text: But it is a very proper subject of inquiry whether this virtue can exist by itself or only in the soul.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 7:5
verses.text: Here again arises a profound discussion, needing lengthy treatment; but perhaps my summary will serve the purpose.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 7:6
verses.text: God will, I trust, assist me, so that, notwithstanding our feebleness, we may give instruction on these great matters briefly as well as intelligibly.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 7:7
verses.text: In either case, whether virtue can exist by itself without the soul, or can exist only in the soul, undoubtedly in the pursuit of virtue the soul follows after something, and this must be either the soul itself, or virtue, or something else.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 7:8
verses.text: But if the soul follows after itself in the pursuit of virtue, it follows after a foolish thing; for before obtaining virtue it is foolish.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 7:9
verses.text: Now the height of a follower's desire is to reach that which he follows after.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 7:10
verses.text: So the soul must either not wish to reach what it follows after, which is utterly absurd and unreasonable, or, in following after itself while foolish, it reaches the folly which it flees from.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 7:11
verses.text: But if it follows after virtue in the desire to reach it, how can it follow what does not exist? or how can it desire to reach what it already possesses? Either, therefore, virtue exists beyond the soul, or if we are not allowed to give the name of virtue except to the habit and disposition of the wise soul, which can exist only in the soul, we must allow that the soul follows after something else in order that virtue may be produced in itself; for neither by following after nothing, nor by following after folly, can the soul, according to my reasoning, attain to wisdom.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 7:12
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 7:13
verses.text: This something else then, by following after which the soul becomes possessed of virtue and wisdom, is either a wise man or God.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 7:14
verses.text: But we have said already that it must be something that we cannot lose against our will.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 7:15
verses.text: No one can think it necessary to ask whether a wise man, supposing we are content to follow after him, can be taken from us in spite of our unwillingness or our persistence.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 7:16
verses.text: God then remains, in following after whom we live well, and in reaching whom we live both well and happily.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 7:17
verses.text: If any deny God's existence, why should I consider the method of dealing with them, when it is doubtful whether they ought to be dealt with at all? At any rate, it would require a different starting-point, a different plan, a different investigation from what we are now engaged in.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 7:18
verses.text: I am now addressing those who do not deny the existence of God, and who, moreover, allow that human affairs are not disregarded by Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 7:19
verses.text: For there is no one, I suppose, who makes any profession of religion but will hold that divine Providence cares at least for our souls.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 8

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 8:1
verses.text: Chapter 7 —The Knowledge of God to Be Obtained from the Scripture.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 8:2
verses.text: The Plan and Principal Mysteries of the Divine Scheme of Redemption.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 8:3
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 8:4
verses.text: But how can we follow after Him whom we do not see? or how can we see Him, we who are not only men, but also men of weak understanding? For though God is seen not with the eyes but with the mind, where can such a mind be found as shall, while obscured by foolishness, succeed or even attempt to drink in that light? We must therefore have recourse to the instructions of those whom we have reason to think wise.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 8:5
verses.text: Thus far argument brings us.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 8:6
verses.text: For in human things reasoning is employed, not as of greater certainty, but as easier from use.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 8:7
verses.text: But when we come to divine things, this faculty turns away; it cannot behold; it pants, and gasps, and burns with desire; it falls back from the light of truth, and turns again to its wonted obscurity, not from choice, but from exhaustion.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 8:8
verses.text: What a dreadful catastrophe is this, that the soul should be reduced to greater helplessness when it is seeking rest from its toil! So, when we are hasting to retire into darkness, it will be well that by the appointment of adorable Wisdom we should be met by the friendly shade of authority, and should be attracted by the wonderful character of its contents, and by the utterances of its pages, which, like shadows, typify and attemper the truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 8:9
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 8:10
verses.text: What more could have been done for our salvation? What can be more gracious and bountiful than divine providence, which, when man had fallen from its laws, and, in just retribution for his coveting mortal things, had brought forth a mortal offspring, still did not wholly abandon him? For in this most righteous government, whose ways are strange and inscrutable, there is, by means of unknown connections established in the creatures subject to it, both a severity of punishment and a mercifulness of salvation.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 8:11
verses.text: How beautiful this is, how great, how worthy of God, in fine, how true, which is all we are seeking for, we shall never be able to perceive, unless, beginning with things human and at hand, and holding by the faith and the precepts of true religion, we continue without turning from it in the way which God has secured for us by the separation of the patriarchs, by the bond of the law, by the foresight of the prophets, by the witness of the apostles, by the blood of the martyrs, and by the subjugation of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 8:12
verses.text: From this point, then, let no one ask me for my opinion, but let us rather hear the oracles, and submit our weak inferences to the announcements of Heaven.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 9

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 9:1
verses.text: Chapter 8 —God is the Chief Good, Whom We are to Seek After with Supreme Affection.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 9:2
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 9:3
verses.text: Let us see how the Lord Himself in the gospel has taught us to live; how, too, Paul the apostle,—for the Manich aeans dare not reject these Scriptures.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 9:4
verses.text: Let us hear, O Christ, what chief end Thou dost prescribe to us; and that is evidently the chief end after which we are told to strive with supreme affection.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 9:5
verses.text: "Thou shalt love," He says, "the Lord thy God".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 9:6
verses.text: Tell me also, I pray Thee, what must be the measure of love; for I fear lest the desire enkindled in my heart should either exceed or come short in fervor.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 9:7
verses.text: "With all thy heart," He says.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 9:8
verses.text: Nor is that enough.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 9:9
verses.text: "With all thy soul".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 9:10
verses.text: Nor is it enough yet.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 9:11
verses.text: "With all thy mind".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 9:12
verses.text: What do you wish more? I might, perhaps, wish more if I could see the possibility of more.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 9:13
verses.text: What does Paul say on this? "We know," he says, "that all things issue in good to them that love God".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 9:14
verses.text: Let him, too, say what is the measure of love.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 9:15
verses.text: "Who then," he says, "shall separate us from the love of Christ? shall tribulation, or distress, or persecution, or famine, or nakedness, or peril, or the sword?"  We have heard, then, what and how much we must love; this we must strive after, and to this we must refer all our plans.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 9:16
verses.text: The perfection of all our good things and our perfect good is God.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 9:17
verses.text: We must neither come short of this nor go beyond it: the one is dangerous, the other impossible.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 10

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 10:1
verses.text: Chapter 9 —Harmony of the Old and New Testament on the Precepts of Charity.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 10:2
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 10:3
verses.text: Come now, let us examine, or rather let us take notice,—for it is obvious and can be seen, at once,—whether the authority of the Old Testament too agrees with those statements taken from the gospel and the apostle.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 10:4
verses.text: What need to speak of the first statement, when it is clear to all that it is a quotation from the law given by Moses? For it is there written, "Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 10:5
verses.text: And not to go farther for a passage of the Old Testament to compare with that of the apostle, he has himself added one.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 10:6
verses.text: For after saying that no tribulation, no distress, no persecution, no pressure of bodily want, no peril, no sword, separates us from the love of Christ, he immediately adds, "As it is written, For Thy sake we are in suffering all the day long; we are accounted as sheep for the slaughter".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 10:7
verses.text: The Manich aeans are in the habit of saying that this is an interpolation,—so unable are they to reply, that they are forced in their extremity to say this.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 10:8
verses.text: But every one can see that this is all that is left for men to say when it is proved that they are wrong.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 10:9
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 10:10
verses.text: And yet I ask them if they deny that this is said in the Old Testament, or if they hold that the passage in the Old Testament does not agree with that of the apostle.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 10:11
verses.text: For the first, the books will prove it; and as for the second, those prevaricators who fly off at a tangent will be brought to agree with me, if they will only reflect a little and consider what is said, or else I will press upon them the opinion of those who judge impartially.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 10:12
verses.text: For what could agree more harmoniously than these passages? For tribulation, distress, persecution, famine, nakedness, peril, cause great suffering to man while in this life.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 10:13
verses.text: So all these words are implied in the single quotation from the law, where it is said, "For Thy sake we are in suffering".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 10:14
verses.text: The only other thing is the sword, which does not inflict a painful life, but removes whatever life it meets with.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 10:15
verses.text: Answering to this are the words, "We are accounted as sheep for the slaughter".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 10:16
verses.text: And love could not have been more plainly expressed than by the words, "For Thy sake".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 10:17
verses.text: Suppose, then, that this testimony is not found in the Apostle Paul, but is quoted by me, must you not prove, you heretic, either that this is not written in the old law, or that it does not harmonize with the apostle? And if you dare not say either of these things (for you are shut up by the reading of the manuscript, which will show that it is written, and by common sense, which sees that nothing could agree better with what is said by the apostle), why do you imagine that there is any force in accusing the Scriptures of being corrupted? And once more, what will you reply to a man who says to you, This is what I understand, this is my view, this is my belief, and I read these books only because I see that everything in them agrees with the Christian faith? Or tell me at once if you will venture deliberately to tell me to the face that we are not to believe that the apostles and martyrs are spoken of as having endured great sufferings for Christ's sake, and as having been accounted by their persecutors as sheep for the slaughter? If you cannot say this, why should you bring a charge against the book in which I find what you acknowledge I ought to believe?.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:1
verses.text: Chapter 10 —What the Church Teaches About God.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:2
verses.text: The Two Gods of the Manich aeans.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:3
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:4
verses.text: Will you say that you grant that we are bound to love God, but not the God worshipped by those who acknowledge the authority of the Old Testament? In that case you refuse to worship the God who made heaven and earth, for this is the God set forth all through these books.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:5
verses.text: And you admit that the whole of the world, which is called heaven and earth, had God and a good God for its author and maker.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:6
verses.text: For in speaking to you about God we must make a distinction.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:7
verses.text: For you hold that there are two gods, one good and the other bad.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:8
verses.text: But if you say that you worship and approve of worshipping the God who made heaven and earth, but not the God supported by the authority of the Old Testament, you act impertinently in trying, though vainly, to attribute to us views and opinions altogether unlike the wholesome and profitable doctrine we really hold.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:9
verses.text: Nor can your silly and profane discourses be at all compared with the expositions in which learned and pious men of the Catholic Church open up those Scriptures to the willing and worthy.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:10
verses.text: Our understanding of the law and the prophets is quite different from what you suppose.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:11
verses.text: Mistake us no longer.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:12
verses.text: We do not worship a God who repents, or is envious, or needy, or cruel, or who takes pleasure in the blood of men or beasts, or is pleased with guilt and crime, or whose possession of the earth is limited to a little corner of it.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:13
verses.text: These and such like are the silly notions you are in the habit of denouncing at great length.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:14
verses.text: Your denunciation does not touch us.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:15
verses.text: The fancies of old women or of children you attack with a vehemence that is only ridiculous.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:16
verses.text: Any one whom you persuade in this way to join you shows no fault in the teaching of the Church, but only proves his own ignorance of it.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:17
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:18
verses.text: If, then, you have any human feeling,—if you have any regard for your own welfare,—you should rather examine with diligence and piety the meaning of these passages of Scripture.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:19
verses.text: You should examine, unhappy beings that you are; for we condemn with no less severity and copiousness any faith which attributes to God what is unbecoming Him, and in those by whom these passages are literally understood we correct the mistake of ignorance, and look upon persistence in it as absurd.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:20
verses.text: And in many other things which you cannot understand there is in the Catholic teaching a check on the belief of those who have got beyond mental childishness, not in years, but in knowledge and understanding—old in the progress towards wisdom.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:21
verses.text: For we learn the folly of believing that God is bounded by any amount of space, even though infinite; and it is held unlawful to think of God, or any part of Him, as moving from one place to another.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:22
verses.text: And should any one suppose that anything in God's substance or nature can suffer change or conversion, he will be held guilty of wild profanity.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:23
verses.text: There are thus among us children who think of God as having a human form, which they suppose He really has, which is a most degrading idea; and there are many of full age to whose mind the majesty of God appears in its inviolableness and unchangeableness as not only above the human body, but above their own mind itself.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:24
verses.text: These ages, as we said, are distinguished not by time, but by virtue and discretion.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:25
verses.text: Among you, again, there is no one who will picture God in a human form; but neither is there one who sets God apart from the contamination of human error.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 11:26
verses.text: As regards those who are fed like crying babies at the breast of the Catholic Church, if they are not carried off by heretics, they are nourished according to the vigor and capacity of each, and arrive at last, one in one way and another in another, first to a perfect man, and then to the maturity and hoary hairs of wisdom, when they may get life as they desire, and life in perfect happiness.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 12

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 12:1
verses.text: Chapter 11 —God is the One Object of Love; Therefore He is Man's Chief Good.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 12:2
verses.text: Nothing is Better Than God.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 12:3
verses.text: God Cannot Be Lost Against Our Will.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 12:4
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 12:5
verses.text: Following after God is the desire of happiness; to reach God is happiness itself.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 12:6
verses.text: We follow after God by loving Him; we reach Him, not by becoming entirely what He is, but in nearness to Him, and in wonderful and immaterial contact with Him, and in being inwardly illuminated and occupied by His truth and holiness.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 12:7
verses.text: He is light itself; we get enlightenment from Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 12:8
verses.text: The greatest commandment, therefore, which leads to happy life, and the first, is this: "Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and soul, and mind".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 12:9
verses.text: For to those who love the Lord all things issue in good.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 12:10
verses.text: Hence Paul adds shortly after, "I am persuaded that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor virtue, nor things present, nor things future, nor height, nor depth, nor any other creature, shall be able to separate us from the love of God, which is in Christ Jesus our Lord".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 12:11
verses.text: If, then, to those who love God all things issue in good, and if, as no one doubts, the chief or perfect good is not only to be loved, but to be loved so that nothing shall be loved better, as is expressed in the words, "With all thy soul, with all thy heart, and with all thy mind," who, I ask, will not at once conclude, when these things are all settled and most surely believed, that our chief good which we must hasten to arrive at in preference to all other things is nothing else than God? And then, if nothing can separate us from His love, must not this be surer as well as better than any other good?  19.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 12:12
verses.text: But let us consider the points separately.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 12:13
verses.text: No one separates us from this by threatening death.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 12:14
verses.text: For that with which we love God cannot die, except in not loving God; for death is not to love God, and that is when we prefer anything to Him in affection and pursuit.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 12:15
verses.text: No one separates us from this in promising life; for no one separates us from the fountain in promising water.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 12:16
verses.text: Angels do not separate us; for the mind cleaving to God is not inferior in strength to an angel.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 12:17
verses.text: Virtue does not separate us; for if what is here called virtue is that which has power in this world, the mind cleaving to God is far above the whole world.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 12:18
verses.text: Or if this virtue is perfect rectitude of our mind itself, this in the case of another will favor our union with God, and in ourselves will itself unite us with God.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 12:19
verses.text: Present troubles do not separate us; for we feel their burden less the closer we cling to Him from whom they try to separate us.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 12:20
verses.text: The promise of future things does not separate us; for both future good of every kind is surest in the promise of God, and nothing is better than God Himself, who undoubtedly is already present to those who truly cleave to Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 12:21
verses.text: Height and depth do not separate us; for if the height and depth of knowledge are what is meant, I will rather not be inquisitive than be separated from God; nor can any instruction by which error is removed separate me from Him, by separation from whom it is that any one is in error.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 12:22
verses.text: Or if what is meant are the higher and lower parts of this world, how can the promise of heaven separate me from Him who made heaven? Or who from beneath can frighten me into forsaking God, when I should not have known of things beneath but by forsaking Him? In fine, what place can remove me from His love, when He could not be all in every place unless He were contained in none?.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 13

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 13:1
verses.text: Chapter 12 —We are United to God by Love, in Subjection to Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 13:2
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 13:3
verses.text: "No other creature," he says, separates us.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 13:4
verses.text: O man of profound mysteries! He thought it not enough to say, no creature: but he says no other creature; teaching that with which we love God and by which we cleave to God, our mind, namely, and understanding, is itself a creature.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 13:5
verses.text: Thus the body is another creature; and if the mind is an object of intellectual perception, and is known only by this means, the other creature is all that is an object of sense, which as it were makes itself known through the eyes, or ears, or smell, or taste, or touch, and this must be inferior to what is perceived by the intellect alone.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 13:6
verses.text: Now, as God also can be known by the worthy, only intellectually,  exalted though He is above the intelligent mind as being its Creator and Author, there was danger lest the human mind, from being reckoned among invisible and immaterial things, should be thought to be of the same nature with Him who created it, and so should fall away by pride from Him to whom it should be united by love.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 13:7
verses.text: For the mind becomes like God, to the extent vouchsafed by its subjection of itself to Him for information and enlightenment.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 13:8
verses.text: And if it obtains the greatest nearness by that subjection which produces likeness, it must be far removed from Him by that presumption which would make the likeness greater.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 13:9
verses.text: It is this presumption which leads the mind to refuse obedience to the laws of God, in the desire to be sovereign, as God is.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 13:10
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 13:11
verses.text: The farther, then, the mind departs from God, not in space, but in affection and lust after things below Him, the more it is filled with folly and wretchedness.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 13:12
verses.text: So by love it returns to God,—a love which places it not along with God, but under Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 13:13
verses.text: And the more ardor and eagerness there is in this, the happier and more elevated will the mind be, and with God as sole governor it will be in perfect liberty.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 13:14
verses.text: Hence it must know that it is a creature.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 13:15
verses.text: It must believe what is the truth,—that its Creator remains ever possessed of the inviolable and immutable nature of truth and wisdom, and must confess, even in view of the errors from which it desires deliverance, that it is liable to folly and falsehood.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 13:16
verses.text: But then again, it must take care that it be not separated by the love of the other creature, that is, of this visible world, from the love of God Himself, which sanctifies it in order to lasting happiness.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 13:17
verses.text: No other creature, then,—for we are ourselves a creature,—separates us from the love of God which is in Christ Jesus our Lord.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 14

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 14:1
verses.text: Chapter 13.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 14:2
verses.text: —We are Joined Inseparably to God by Christ and His Spirit.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 14:3
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 14:4
verses.text: Let this same Paul tell us who is this Christ Jesus our Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 14:5
verses.text: "To them that are called," he says, "we preach Christ the virtue of God, and the wisdom of God".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 14:6
verses.text: And does not Christ Himself say, "I am the truth?"  If, then, we ask what it is to live well,—that is, to strive after happiness by living well,—it must assuredly be to love virtue, to love wisdom, to love truth, and to love with all the heart, with all the soul, and with all the mind; virtue which is inviolable and immutable, wisdom which never gives place to folly, truth which knows no change or variation from its uniform character.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 14:7
verses.text: Through this the Father Himself is seen; for it is said, "No man cometh unto the Father but by me".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 14:8
verses.text: To this we cleave by sanctification.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 14:9
verses.text: For when sanctified we burn with full and perfect love, which is the only security for our not turning away from God, and for our being conformed to Him rather than to this world; for "He has predestinated us," says the same apostle, "that we should be conformed to the image of His Son".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 14:10
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 14:11
verses.text: It is through love, then, that we become conformed to God; and by this conformation, and configuration, and circumcision from this world we are not confounded with the things which are properly subject to us.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 14:12
verses.text: And this is done by the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 14:13
verses.text: "For hope," he says, "does not confound us; for the love of God is shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Spirit, which is given unto us".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 14:14
verses.text: But we could not possibly be restored to perfection by the Holy Spirit, unless He Himself continued always perfect and immutable.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 14:15
verses.text: And this plainly could not be unless He were of the nature and of the very substance of God, who alone is always possessed of immutability and invariableness.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 14:16
verses.text: "The creature," it is affirmed, not by me but by Paul, "has been made subject to vanity".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 14:17
verses.text: And what is subject to vanity is unable to separate us from vanity, and to unite us to the truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 14:18
verses.text: But the Holy Spirit does this for us.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 14:19
verses.text: He is therefore no creature.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 14:20
verses.text: For whatever is, must be either God or the creature.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 15

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 15:1
verses.text: Chapter 14.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 15:2
verses.text: —We Cleave to the Trinity, Our Chief Good, by Love.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 15:3
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 15:4
verses.text: We ought then to love God, the Trinity in unity, Father, Son, and Holy Spirit; for this must be said to be God Himself, for it is said of God, truly and in the most exalted sense, "Of whom are all things, by whom are all things, in whom are all things".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 15:5
verses.text: Those are Paul's words.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 15:6
verses.text: And what does he add? "To Him be glory".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 15:7
verses.text: All this is exactly true.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 15:8
verses.text: He does not say, To them; for God is one.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 15:9
verses.text: And what is meant by, To Him be glory, but to Him be chief and perfect and widespread praise? For as the praise improves and extends, so the love and affection increases in fervor.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 15:10
verses.text: And when this is the case, mankind cannot but advance with sure and firm step to a life of perfection and bliss.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 15:11
verses.text: This, I suppose, is all we wish to find when we speak of the chief good of man, to which all must be referred in life and conduct.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 15:12
verses.text: For the good plainly exists; and we have shown by reasoning, as far as we were able, and by the divine authority which goes beyond our reasoning, that it is nothing else but God Himself.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 15:13
verses.text: For how can any thing be man's chief good but that in cleaving to which he is blessed? Now this is nothing but God, to whom we can cleave only by affection, desire, and love.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 16

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 16:1
verses.text: Chapter 15.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 16:2
verses.text: —The Christian Definition of the Four Virtues.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 16:3
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 16:4
verses.text: As to virtue leading us to a happy life, I hold virtue to be nothing else than perfect love of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 16:5
verses.text: For the fourfold division of virtue I regard as taken from four forms of love.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 16:6
verses.text: For these four virtues (would that all felt their influence in their minds as they have their names in their mouths!), I should have no hesitation in defining them: that temperance is love giving itself entirely to that which is loved; fortitude is love readily bearing all things for the sake of the loved object; justice is love serving only the loved object, and therefore ruling rightly; prudence is love distinguishing with sagacity between what hinders it and what helps it.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 16:7
verses.text: The object of this love is not anything, but only God, the chief good, the highest wisdom, the perfect harmony.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 16:8
verses.text: So we may express the definition thus: that temperance is love keeping itself entire and incorrupt for God; fortitude is love bearing everything readily for the sake of God; justice is love serving God only, and therefore ruling well all else, as subject to man; prudence is love making a right distinction between what helps it towards God and what might hinder it.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:1
verses.text: Chapter 16.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:2
verses.text: —Harmony of the Old and New Testaments.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:3
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:4
verses.text: I will briefly set forth the manner of life according to these virtues, one by one, after I have brought forward, as I promised, passages from the Old Testament parallel to those I have been quoting from the New Testament.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:5
verses.text: For is Paul alone in saying that we should be joined to God so that there should be nothing between to separate us? Does not the prophet say the same most aptly and concisely in the words, "It is good for me to cleave to God?"   Does not this one word cleave express all that the apostle says at length about love? And do not the words, It is good, point to the apostle's statement, "All things issue in good to them that love God?" Thus in one clause and in two words the prophet sets forth the power and the fruit of love.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:6
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:7
verses.text: And as the apostle says that the Son of God is the virtue of God and the wisdom of God,—virtue being understood to refer to action, and wisdom to teaching (as in the gospel these two things are expressed in the words, "All things were made by Him," which belongs to action and virtue; and then, referring to teaching and the knowledge of the truth, he says, "The life was the light of men" ),—could anything agree better with these passages than what is said in the Old Testament  of wisdom, "She reaches from end to end in strength, and orders all things sweetly?" For reaching in strength expresses virtue, while ordering sweetly expresses skill and method.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:8
verses.text: But if this seems obscure, see what follows: "And of all," he says, "God loved her; for she teaches the knowledge of God, and chooses His works".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:9
verses.text: Nothing more is found here about action; for choosing works is not the same as working, so this refers to teaching.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:10
verses.text: There remains action to correspond with the virtue, to complete the truth we wish to prove.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:11
verses.text: Read then what comes next: "But if," he says, "the possession which is desired in life is honorable, what is more honorable than wisdom, which works all things?" Could anything be brought forward more striking or more distinct than this, or even more fully expressed? Or, if you wish more, hear another passage of the same meaning.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:12
verses.text: "Wisdom," he says, "teaches sobriety, and justice, and virtue".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:13
verses.text: Sobriety refers, I think, to the knowledge of the truth, or to teaching; justice and virtue to work and action.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:14
verses.text: And I know nothing comparable to these two things, that is, to efficiency in action and sobriety in contemplation, which the virtue of God and the wisdom of God, that is, the Son of God, gives to them that love Him, when the same prophet goes on to show their value; for it is thus stated: "Wisdom teaches sobriety, and justice, and virtue, than which nothing is more useful in life to man".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:15
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:16
verses.text: Perhaps some may think that those passages do not refer to the Son of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:17
verses.text: What, then, is taught in the following words: "She displays the nobility of her birth, having her dwelling with God?"  To what does birth refer but to parentage? And does not dwelling with the Father claim and assert equality? Again, as Paul says that the Son of God is the wisdom of God,  and as the Lord Himself says, "No man knoweth the Father save the only-begotten Son,"  what could be more concordant than those words of the prophet: "With Thee is wisdom which knows Thy works, which was present at the time of Thy making the world, and knew what would be pleasing in Thine eyes?"  And as Christ is called the truth, which is also taught by His being called the brightness of the Father  (for there is nothing round about the sun but its brightness which is produced from it), what is there in the Old Testament more plainly and obviously in accordance with this than the words, "Thy truth is round about Thee?"  Once more, Wisdom herself says in the gospel, "No man cometh unto the Father but by me;"  and the prophet says, "Who knoweth Thy mind, unless Thou givest wisdom?" and a little after, "The things pleasing to Thee men have learned, and have been healed by wisdom".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:18
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:19
verses.text: Paul says, "The love of God is shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Spirit which is given unto us;"  and the prophet says, "The Holy Spirit of knowledge will shun guile".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:20
verses.text: For where there is guile there is no love.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:21
verses.text: Paul says that we are "conformed to the image of the Son of God;"  and the prophet says, "The light of Thy countenance is stamped upon us".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:22
verses.text: Paul teaches that the Holy Spirit is God, and therefore is no creature; and the prophet says, "Thou sendest Thy Spirit from the higher".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:23
verses.text: For God alone is the highest, than whom nothing is higher.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 17:24
verses.text: Paul shows that the Trinity is one God, when he says, "To Him be glory;"[19] and in the Old Testament it is said, "Hear, O Israel, the Lord thy God is one God".

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:1
verses.text: Chapter 17.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:2
verses.text: —Appeal to the Manich aeans, Calling on Them to Repent.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:3
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:4
verses.text: What more do you wish? Why do you resist ignorantly and obstinately? Why do you pervert untutored minds by your mischievous teaching? The God of both Testaments is one.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:5
verses.text: For as there is an agreement in the passages quoted from both, so is there in all the rest, if you are willing to consider them carefully and impartially.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:6
verses.text: But because many expressions are undignified, and so far adapted to minds creeping on the earth, that they may rise by human things to divine,  while many are figurative, that the inquiring mind may have the more profit from the exertion of finding their meaning, and the more delight when it is found, you pervert this admirable arrangement of the Holy Spirit for the purpose of deceiving and ensnaring your followers.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:7
verses.text: As to the reason why divine Providence permits you to do this, and as to the truth of the apostle's saying, "There must needs be many heresies, that they which are approved may be made manifest among you,"  it would take long to discuss these things, and you, with whom we have now to do, are not capable of understanding them.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:8
verses.text: I know you well.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:9
verses.text: To the consideration of divine things, which are far higher than you suppose, you bring minds quite gross and sickly, from being fed with material images.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:10
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:11
verses.text: We must therefore in your case try not to make you understand divine things, which is impossible, but to make you desire to understand.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:12
verses.text: This is the work of the pure and guileless love of God, which is seen chiefly in the conduct, and of which we have already said much.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:13
verses.text: This love, inspired by the Holy Spirit, leads to the Son, that is, to the wisdom of God, by which the Father Himself is known.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:14
verses.text: For if wisdom and truth are not sought for with the whole strength of the mind, it cannot possibly be found.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:15
verses.text: But when it is sought as it deserves to be, it cannot withdraw or hide itself from its lovers.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:16
verses.text: Hence its words, which you too are in the habit of repeating, "Ask, and ye shall receive; seek, and ye shall find; knock, and it shall be opened unto you:"  "Nothing is hid which shall not be revealed".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:17
verses.text: It is love that asks, love that seeks, love that knocks, love that reveals, love, too, that gives continuance in what is revealed.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:18
verses.text: From this love of wisdom, and this studious inquiry, we are not debarred by the Old Testament, as you always say most falsely, but are exhorted to this with the greatest urgency.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:19
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:20
verses.text: Hear, then, at length, and consider, I pray you, what is said by the prophet: "Wisdom is glorious, and never fadeth away; yea, she is easily seen of them that love her, and found of such as seek her.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:21
verses.text: She preventeth them that desire her, in making herself first known unto them.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:22
verses.text: Whoso seeketh her early shall have no great travail; for he shall find her sitting at his doors.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:23
verses.text: To think, therefore, upon her is perfection of wisdom; and whoso watcheth for her shall quickly be without care.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:24
verses.text: For she goeth about seeking such as are worthy of her, showeth herself favorably unto them in the ways, and meeteth them in every thought.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:25
verses.text: For the very true beginning of her is the desire of discipline; and the care of discipline is love; and love is the keeping of her laws; and the giving heed unto her laws is the assurance of incorruption; and incorruption maketh us near unto God.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:26
verses.text: Therefore the desire of wisdom bringeth to a kingdom".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 18:27
verses.text: Will you still continue in dogged hostility to these things? Do not things thus stated, though not yet understood, make it evident to every one that they contain something deep and unutterable? Would that you could understand the things here said! Forthwith you would abjure all your silly legends and your unmeaning material imaginations, and with great alacrity, sincere love, and full assurance of faith, would betake yourselves bodily to the shelter of the most holy bosom of the Catholic Church.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 19

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 19:1
verses.text: Chapter 18.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 19:2
verses.text: —Only in the Catholic Church is Perfect Truth Established on the Harmony of Both Testaments.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 19:3
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 19:4
verses.text: I could, according to the little ability I have, take up the points separately, and could expound and prove the truths I have learned, which are generally more excellent and lofty than words can express; but this cannot be done while you bark at it.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 19:5
verses.text: For not in vain is it said, "Give not that which is holy to dogs".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 19:6
verses.text: Do not be angry.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 19:7
verses.text: I too barked and was a dog; and then, as was right, instead of the food of teaching, I got the rod of correction.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 19:8
verses.text: But were there in you that love of which we are speaking, or should it ever be in you as much as the greatness of the truth to be known requires, may God vouchsafe to show you that neither is there among the Manich aeans the Christian faith which leads to the summit of wisdom and truth, the attainment of which is the true happy life, nor is it anywhere but in the Catholic teaching.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 19:9
verses.text: Is not this what the Apostle Paul appears to desire when he says, "For this cause I bow my knees to the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, from whom the whole family in heaven and earth is named, that He would grant unto you, according to the riches of His glory, to be strengthened with might by His Spirit in the inner man: that Christ may dwell in your hearts by faith; that ye, being rooted and grounded in love, may be able to comprehend with all saints what is the height, and length, and breadth, and depth, and to know the love of Christ, which passeth knowledge, that ye may be filled with all the fullness of God?"  Could anything be more plainly expressed?  34.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 19:10
verses.text: Wake up a little, I beseech you, and see the harmony of both Testaments, making it quite plain and certain what should be the manner of life in our conduct, and to what all things should be referred.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 19:11
verses.text: To the love of God we are incited by the gospel, when it is said, "Ask, seek, knock;"  by Paul, when he says, "That ye, being rooted and grounded in love, may be able to comprehend;"  by the prophet also, when he says that wisdom can easily be known by those who love it, seek for it, desire it, watch for it, think about it, care for it.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 19:12
verses.text: The salvation of the mind  and the way of happiness is pointed out by the concord of both Scriptures; and yet you choose rather to bark at these things than to obey them.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 19:13
verses.text: I will tell you in one word what I think.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 19:14
verses.text: Do you listen to the learned men of the Catholic Church with as peaceable a disposition, and with the same zeal, that I had when for nine years I attended on you:  there will be no need of so long a time as that during which you made a fool of me.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 19:15
verses.text: In a much, a very much, shorter time you will see the difference between truth and vanity.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 20

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 20:1
verses.text: Chapter 19.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 20:2
verses.text: —Description of the Duties of Temperance, According to the Sacred Scriptures.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 20:3
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 20:4
verses.text: It is now time to return to the four virtues, and to draw out and prescribe a way of life in conformity with them, taking each separately.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 20:5
verses.text: First, then, let us consider temperance, which promises us a kind of integrity and incorruption in the love by which we are united to God.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 20:6
verses.text: The office of temperance is in restraining and quieting the passions which make us pant for those things which turn us away from the laws of God and from the enjoyment of His goodness, that is, in a word, from the happy life.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 20:7
verses.text: For there is the abode of truth; and in enjoying its contemplation, and in cleaving closely to it, we are assuredly happy; but departing from this, men become entangled in great errors and sorrows.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 20:8
verses.text: For, as the apostle says, "The root of all evils is covetousness; which some having followed, have made shipwreck of the faith, and have pierced themselves through with many sorrows".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 20:9
verses.text: And this sin of the soul is quite plainly, to those rightly understanding, set forth in the Old Testament in the transgression of Adam in Paradise.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 20:10
verses.text: Thus, as the apostle says, "In Adam we all die, and in Christ we shall all rise again".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 20:11
verses.text: Oh, the depth of these mysteries! But I refrain; for I am now engaged not in teaching you the truth, but in making you unlearn your errors, if I can, that is, if God aid my purpose regarding you.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 20:12
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 20:13
verses.text: Paul then says that covetousness is the root of all evils; and by covetousness the old law also intimates that the first man fell.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 20:14
verses.text: Paul tells us to put off the old man and put on the new.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 20:15
verses.text: By the old man he means Adam who sinned, and by the new man him whom the Son of God took to Himself in consecration for our redemption.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 20:16
verses.text: For he says in another place, "The first man is of the earth, earthy; the second man is from heaven, heavenly.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 20:17
verses.text: As is the earthy, such are they also that are earthy; and as is the heavenly, such are they also that are heavenly.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 20:18
verses.text: And as we have borne the image of the earthy, let us also bear the image of the heavenly,"  —that is, put off the old man, and put on the new.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 20:19
verses.text: The whole duty of temperance, then, is to put off the old man, and to be renewed in God,—that is, to scorn all bodily delights, and the popular applause, and to turn the whole love to things divine and unseen.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 20:20
verses.text: Hence that following passage which is so admirable: "Though our outward man perish, our inward man is renewed day by day".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 20:21
verses.text: Hear, too, the prophet singing, "Create in me a clean heart, O God, and renew a right spirit within me".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 20:22
verses.text: What can be said against such harmony except by blind barkers?.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 21

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 21:1
verses.text: Chapter 20.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 21:2
verses.text: —We are Required to Despise All Sensible Things, and to Love God Alone.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 21:3
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 21:4
verses.text: Bodily delights have their source in all those things with which the bodily sense comes in contact, and which are by some called the objects of sense; and among these the noblest is light, in the common meaning of the word, because among our senses also, which the mind uses in acting through the body, there is nothing more valuable than the eyes, and so in the Holy Scriptures all the objects of sense are spoken of as visible things.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 21:5
verses.text: Thus in the New Testament we are warned against the love of these things in the following words: "While we look not at the things which are seen, but at the things which are not seen; for the things which are seen are temporal, but the things which are not seen are eternal".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 21:6
verses.text: This shows how far from being Christians those are who hold that the sun and moon are to be not only loved but worshipped.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 21:7
verses.text: For what is seen if the sun and moon are not? But we are forbidden to regard things which are seen.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 21:8
verses.text: The man, therefore, who wishes to offer that incorrupt love to God must not love these things too.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 21:9
verses.text: This subject I will inquire into more particularly elsewhere.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 21:10
verses.text: Here my plan is to write not of faith, but of the life by which we become worthy of knowing what we believe.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 21:11
verses.text: God then alone is to be loved; and all this world, that is, all sensible things, are to be despised,—while, however, they are to be used as this life requires.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 22

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 22:1
verses.text: Chapter 21.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 22:2
verses.text: —Popular Renown and Inquisitiveness are Condemned in the Sacred Scriptures.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 22:3
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 22:4
verses.text: Popular renown is thus slighted and scorned in the New Testament: "If I wished," says St.
