verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 22:5
verses.text: Paul, "to please men, I should not be the servant of Christ".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 22:6
verses.text: Again, there is another production of the soul formed by imaginations derived from material things, and called the knowledge of things.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 22:7
verses.text: In reference to this we are fitly warned against inquisitiveness to correct which is the great function of temperance.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 22:8
verses.text: Thus it is said, "Take heed lest any one seduce you by philosophy".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 22:9
verses.text: And because the word philosophy originally means the love and pursuit of wisdom, a thing of great value and to be sought with the whole mind, the apostle, with great prudence, that he might not be thought to deter from the love of wisdom, has added the words, "And the elements of this world".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 22:10
verses.text: For some people, neglecting virtues, and ignorant of what God is, and of the majesty of nature which remains always the same, think that they are engaged in an important business when searching with the greatest inquisitiveness and eagerness into this material mass which we call the world.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 22:11
verses.text: This begets so much pride, that they look upon themselves as inhabitants of the heaven of which they often discourse.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 22:12
verses.text: The soul, then, which purposes to keep itself chaste for God must refrain from the desire of vain knowledge like this.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 22:13
verses.text: For this desire usually produces delusion, so that the soul thinks that nothing exists but what is material; or if, from regard to authority, it confesses that there is an immaterial existence, it can think of it only under material images, and has no belief regarding it but that imposed by the bodily sense.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 22:14
verses.text: We may apply to this the precept about fleeing from idolatry.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 22:15
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 22:16
verses.text: To this New Testament authority, requiring us not to love anything in this world,  especially in that passage where it is said, "Be not conformed to this world," —for the point is to show that a man is conformed to whatever he loves,—to this authority, then, if I seek for a parallel passage in the Old Testament, I find several; but there is one book of Solomon, called Ecclesiastes, which at great length brings all earthly things into utter contempt.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 22:17
verses.text: The book begins thus: "Vanity of the vain, saith the Preacher, vanity of the vain; all is vanity.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 22:18
verses.text: What profit hath a man of all his labor which he taketh under the sun?"   If all these words are considered, weighed, and thoroughly examined, many things are found of essential importance to those who seek to flee from the world and to take shelter in God; but this requires time and our discourse hastens on to other topics.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 22:19
verses.text: But, after this beginning, he goes on to show in detail that the vain  are those who are deceived by things of this sort; and he calls this which deceives them vanity,—not that God did not create those things, but because men choose to subject themselves by their sins to those things, which the divine law has made subject to them in well-doing.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 22:20
verses.text: For when you consider things beneath yourself to be admirable and desirable, what is this but to be cheated and misled by unreal goods? The man, then, who is temperate in such mortal and transient things has his rule of life confirmed by both Testaments, that he should love none of these things, nor think them desirable for their own sakes, but should use them as far as is required for the purposes and duties of life, with the moderation of an employer instead of the ardor of a lover.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 22:21
verses.text: These remarks on temperance are few in proportion to the greatness of the theme, but perhaps too many in view of the task on hand.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 23

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 23:1
verses.text: Chapter 22.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 23:2
verses.text: —Fortitude Comes from the Love of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 23:3
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 23:4
verses.text: On fortitude we must be brief.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 23:5
verses.text: The love, then, of which we speak, which ought with all sanctity to burn in desire for God, is called temperance, in not seeking for earthly things, and fortitude in bearing the loss of them.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 23:6
verses.text: But among all things which are possessed in this life, the body is, by God's most righteous laws, for the sin of old, man's heaviest bond, which is well known as a fact but most incomprehensible in its mystery.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 23:7
verses.text: Lest this bond should be shaken and disturbed, the soul is shaken with the fear of toil and pain; lest it should be lost and destroyed, the soul is shaken with the fear of death.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 23:8
verses.text: For the soul loves it from the force of habit, not knowing that by using it well and wisely its resurrection and reformation will, by the divine help and decree, be without any trouble made subject to its authority.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 23:9
verses.text: But when the soul turns to God wholly in this love, it knows these things, and so will not only disregard death, but will even desire it.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 23:10
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 23:11
verses.text: Then there is the great struggle with pain.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 23:12
verses.text: But there is nothing, though of iron hardness, which the fire of love cannot subdue.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 23:13
verses.text: And when the mind is carried up to God in this love, it will soar above all torture free and glorious, with wings beauteous and unhurt, on which chaste love rises to the embrace of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 23:14
verses.text: Otherwise God must allow the lovers of gold, the lovers of praise, the lovers of women, to have more fortitude than the lovers of Himself, though love in those cases is rather to be called passion or lust.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 23:15
verses.text: And yet even here we may see with what force the mind presses on with unflagging energy, in spite of all alarms, towards that it loves; and we learn that we should bear all things rather than forsake God, since those men bear so much in order to forsake Him.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 24

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 24:1
verses.text: Chapter 23.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 24:2
verses.text: —Scripture Precepts and Examples of Fortitude.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 24:3
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 24:4
verses.text: Instead of quoting here authorities from the New Testament, where it is said, "Tribulation worketh patience; and patience, experience and experience, hope;"  and where, in addition to these words, there is proof and confirmation of them from the example of those who spoke them; I will rather summon an example of patience from the Old Testament, against which the Manich aeans make fierce assaults.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 24:5
verses.text: Nor will I refer to the man who, in the midst of great bodily suffering, and with a dreadful disease in his limbs, not only bore human evils, but discoursed of things divine.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 24:6
verses.text: Whoever gives considerate attention to the utterances of this man, will learn from every one of them what value is to be attached to those things which men try to keep in their power, and in so doing are themselves brought by passion into bondage, so that they become the slaves of mortal things, while seeking ignorantly to be their masters.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 24:7
verses.text: This man, in the loss of all his wealth, and on being suddenly reduced to the greatest poverty, kept his mind so unshaken and fixed upon God, as to manifest that these things were not great in his view, but that he was great in relation to them, and God to him.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 24:8
verses.text: If this mind were to be found in men in our day, we should not be so strongly cautioned in the New Testament against the possession of these things in order that we may be perfect; for to have these things without cleaving to them is much more admirable than not to have them at all.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 24:9
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 24:10
verses.text: But since we are speaking here of bearing pain and bodily sufferings, I pass from this man, great as he was, indomitable as he was: this is the case of a man.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 24:11
verses.text: But these Scriptures present to me a woman of amazing fortitude, and I must at once go on to her case.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 24:12
verses.text: This woman, along with seven children, allowed the tyrant and executioner to extract her vitals from her body rather than a profane word from her mouth, encouraging her sons by her exhortations, though she suffered in the tortures of their bodies, and was herself to undergo what she called on them to bear.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 24:13
verses.text: What patience could be greater than this? And yet why should we be astonished that the love of God, implanted in her inmost heart, bore up against tyrant, and executioner, and pain, and sex, and natural affection? Had she not heard, "Precious in the sight of the Lord is the death of His saints?"  Had she not heard, "A patient man is better than the mightiest?"  Had she not heard, "All that is appointed thee receive; and in pain bear it; and in abasement keep thy patience: for in fire are gold and silver tried?"  Had she not heard, "The fire tries the vessels of the potter, and for just men is the trial of tribulation?"  These she knew, and many other precepts of fortitude written in these books, which alone existed at that time, by the same divine Spirit who writes those in the New Testament.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 25

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 25:1
verses.text: Chapter 24.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 25:2
verses.text: —Of Justice and Prudence.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 25:3
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 25:4
verses.text: What of justice that pertains to God? As the Lord says, "Ye cannot serve two masters,"  and the apostle denounces those who serve the creature rather than the Creator,  was it not said before in the Old Testament, "Thou shalt worship the Lord thy God, and Him only shalt thou serve?"  I need say no more on this, for these books are full of such passages.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 25:5
verses.text: The lover, then, whom we are describing, will get from justice this rule of life, that he must with perfect readiness serve the God whom he loves, the highest good, the highest wisdom, the highest peace;  and as regards all other things, must either rule them as subject to himself, or treat them with a view to their subjection.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 25:6
verses.text: This rule of life, is, as we have shown, confirmed by the authority of both Testaments.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 25:7
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 25:8
verses.text: With equal brevity we must treat of prudence, to which it belongs to discern between what is to be desired and what to be shunned.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 25:9
verses.text: Without this, nothing can be done of what we have already spoken of.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 25:10
verses.text: It is the part of prudence to keep watch with most anxious vigilance, lest any evil influence should stealthily creep in upon us.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 25:11
verses.text: Thus the Lord often exclaims, "Watch;"  and He says, "Walk while ye have the light, lest darkness come upon you".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 25:12
verses.text: And then it is said, "Know ye not that a little leaven leaveneth the whole lump?"  And no passage can be quoted from the Old Testament more expressly condemning this mental somnolence, which makes us insensible to destruction advancing on us step by step, than those words of the prophet, "He who despiseth small things shall fall by degrees".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 25:13
verses.text: On this topic I might discourse at length did our haste allow of it.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 25:14
verses.text: And did our present task demand it, we might perhaps prove the depth of these mysteries, by making a mock of which profane men in their perfect ignorance fall, not certainly by degrees, but with a headlong overthrow.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 26

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 26:1
verses.text: Chapter 25.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 26:2
verses.text: —Four Moral Duties Regarding the Love of God, of Which Love the Reward is Eternal Life and the Knowledge of the Truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 26:3
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 26:4
verses.text: I need say no more about right conduct.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 26:5
verses.text: For if God is man's chief good, which you cannot deny, it clearly follows, since to seek the chief good is to live well, that to live well is nothing else but to love God with all the heart, with all the soul, with all the mind; and, as arising from this, that this love must be preserved entire and incorrupt, which is the part of temperance; that it give way before no troubles, which is the part of fortitude; that it serve no other, which is the part of justice; that it be watchful in its inspection of things lest craft or fraud steal in, which is the part of prudence.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 26:6
verses.text: This is the one perfection of man, by which alone he can succeed in attaining to the purity of truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 26:7
verses.text: This both Testaments enjoin in concert; this is commended on both sides alike.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 26:8
verses.text: Why do you continue to cast reproaches on Scriptures of which you are ignorant? Do you not see the folly of your attack upon books which only those who do not understand them find fault with, and which only those who find fault fail in understanding? For neither can an enemy know them, nor can one who knows them be other than a friend to them.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 26:9
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 26:10
verses.text: Let us then, as many as have in view to reach eternal life, love God with all the heart, with all the soul, with all the mind.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 26:11
verses.text: For eternal life contains the whole reward in the promise of which we rejoice; nor can the reward precede desert, nor be given to a man before he is worthy of it.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 26:12
verses.text: What can be more unjust than this, and what is more just than God? We should not then demand the reward before we deserve to get it.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 26:13
verses.text: Here, perhaps, it is not out of place to ask what is eternal life; or rather let us hear the Bestower of it: "This," He says, "is life eternal, that they should know Thee, the true God, and Jesus Christ whom Thou hast sent".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 26:14
verses.text: So eternal life is the knowledge of the truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 26:15
verses.text: See, then, how perverse and preposterous is the character of those who think that their teaching of the knowledge of God will make us perfect, when this is the reward of those already perfect! What else, then, have we to do but first to love with full affection Him whom we desire to know?  Hence arises that principle on which we have all along insisted, that there is nothing more wholesome in the Catholic Church than using authority  before argument.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:1
verses.text: Chapter 26.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:2
verses.text: —Love of Ourselves and of Our Neighbor.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:3
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:4
verses.text: To proceed to what remains.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:5
verses.text: It may be thought that there is nothing here about man himself, the lover.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:6
verses.text: But to think this, shows a want of clear perception.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:7
verses.text: For it is impossible for one who loves God not to love himself.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:8
verses.text: For he alone has a proper love for himself who aims diligently at the attainment of the chief and true good; and if this is nothing else but God, as has been shown, what is to prevent one who loves God from loving himself? And then, among men should there be no bond of mutual love? Yea, verily; so that we can think of no surer step towards the love of God than the love of man to man.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:9
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:10
verses.text: Let the Lord then supply us with the other precept in answer to the question about the precepts of life; for He was not satisfied with one as knowing that God is one thing and man another, and that the difference is nothing less than that between the Creator and the thing created in the likeness of its Creator.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:11
verses.text: He says then that the second precept is, "Thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:12
verses.text: Now you love yourself suitably when you love God better than yourself.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:13
verses.text: What, then, you aim at in yourself you must aim at in your neighbor, namely, that he may love God with a perfect affection.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:14
verses.text: For you do not love him as yourself, unless you try to draw him to that good which you are yourself pursuing.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:15
verses.text: For this is the one good which has room for all to pursue it along with thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:16
verses.text: From this precept proceed the duties of human society, in which it is hard to keep from error.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:17
verses.text: But the first thing to aim at is, that we should be benevolent, that is, that we cherish no malice and no evil design against another.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:18
verses.text: For man is the nearest neighbor of man.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:19
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:20
verses.text: Hear also what Paul says: "The love of our neighbor," he says, "worketh no ill".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:21
verses.text: The testimonies here made use of are very short, but, if I mistake not, they are to the point, and sufficient for the purpose.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:22
verses.text: And every one knows how many and how weighty are the words to be found everywhere in these books on the love of our neighbor.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:23
verses.text: But as a man may sin against another in two ways, either by injuring him or by not helping him when it is in his power, and as it is for these things which no loving man would do that men are called wicked, all that is required is, I think, proved by these words, "The love of our neighbor worketh no ill".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:24
verses.text: And if we cannot attain to good unless we first desist from working evil, our love of our neighbor is a sort of cradle of our love to God, so that, as it is said, "the love of our neighbor worketh no ill," we may rise from this to these other words, "We know that all things issue in good to them that love God".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:25
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:26
verses.text: But there is a sense in which these either rise together to fullness and perfection, or, while the love of God is first in beginning, the love of our neighbor is first in coming to perfection.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:27
verses.text: For perhaps divine love takes hold on us more rapidly at the outset, but we reach perfection more easily in lower things.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:28
verses.text: However that may be, the main point is this, that no one should think that while he despises his neighbor he will come to happiness and to the God whom he loves.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:29
verses.text: And would that it were as easy to seek the good of our neighbor, or to avoid hurting him, as it is for one well trained and kind-hearted to love his neighbor! These things require more than mere good-will, and can be done only by a high degree of thoughtfulness and prudence, which belongs only to those to whom it is given by God, the source of all good.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 27:30
verses.text: On this topic—which is one, I think, of great difficulty—I will try to say a few words such as my plan admits of, resting all my hope in Him whose gifts these are.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 28

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 28:1
verses.text: Chapter 27.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 28:2
verses.text: —On Doing Good to the Body of Our Neighbor.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 28:3
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 28:4
verses.text: Man, then, as viewed by his fellow-man, is a rational soul with a mortal and earthly body in its service.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 28:5
verses.text: Therefore he who loves his neighbor does good partly to the man's body, and partly to his soul.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 28:6
verses.text: What benefits the body is called medicine; what benefits the soul, discipline.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 28:7
verses.text: Medicine here includes everything that either preserves or restores bodily health.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 28:8
verses.text: It includes, therefore, not only what belongs to the art of medical men, properly so called, but also food and drink, clothing and shelter, and every means of covering and protection to guard our bodies against injuries and mishaps from without as well as from within.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 28:9
verses.text: For hunger and thirst, and cold and heat, and all violence from without, produce loss of that health which is the point to be considered.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 28:10
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 28:11
verses.text: Hence those who seasonably and wisely supply all the things required for warding off these evils and distresses are called compassionate, although they may have been so wise that no painful feeling disturbed their mind in the exercise of compassion.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 28:12
verses.text: No doubt the word compassionate implies suffering in the heart of the man who feels for the sorrow of another.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 28:13
verses.text: And it is equally true that a wise man ought to be free from all painful emotion when he assists the needy, when he gives food to the hungry and water to the thirsty, when he clothes the naked, when he takes the stranger into his house, when he sets free the oppressed, when, lastly, he extends his charity to the dead in giving them burial.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 28:14
verses.text: Still the epithet compassionate is a proper one, although he acts with tranquillity of mind, not from the stimulus of painful feeling, but from motives of benevolence.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 28:15
verses.text: There is no harm in the word compassionate when there is no passion in the case.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 28:16
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 28:17
verses.text: Fools, again, who avoid the exercise of compassion as a vice, because they are not sufficiently moved by a sense of duty without feeling also distressful emotion, are frozen into hard insensibility, which is very different from the calm of a rational serenity.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 28:18
verses.text: God, on the other hand, is properly called compassionate; and the sense in which He is so will be understood by those whom piety and diligence have made fit to understand.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 28:19
verses.text: There is a danger lest, in using the words of the learned, we harden the souls of the unlearned by leading them away from compassion instead of softening them with the desire of a charitable disposition.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 28:20
verses.text: As compassion, then, requires us to ward off these distresses from others, so harmlessness forbids the infliction of them.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:1
verses.text: Chapter 28.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:2
verses.text: —On Doing Good to the Soul of Our Neighbor.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:3
verses.text: Two Parts of Discipline, Restraint and Instruction.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:4
verses.text: Through Good Conduct We Arrive at the Knowledge of the Truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:5
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:6
verses.text: As regards discipline, by which the health of the mind is restored, without which bodily health avails nothing for security against misery, the subject is one of great difficulty.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:7
verses.text: And as in the body we said it is one thing to cure diseases and wounds, which few can do properly, and another thing to meet the cravings of hunger and thirst, and to give assistance in all the other ways in which any man may at any time help another; so in the mind there are some things in which the high and rare offices of the teacher are not much called for,—as, for instance, in advice and exhortation to give to the needy the things already mentioned as required for the body.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:8
verses.text: To give such advice is to aid the mind by discipline, as giving the things themselves is aiding the body by our resources.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:9
verses.text: But there are other cases where diseases of the mind, many and various in kind, are healed in a way strange and indescribable.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:10
verses.text: Unless His medicine were sent from heaven to men, so heedlessly do they go on in sin, there would be no hope of salvation; and, indeed, even bodily health, if you go to the root of the matter, can have come to men from none but God, who gives to all things their being and their well-being.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:11
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:12
verses.text: This discipline, then, which is the medicine of the mind, as far as we can gather from the sacred Scriptures, includes two things, restraint and instruction.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:13
verses.text: Restraint implies fear, and instruction love, in the person benefited by the discipline; for in the giver of the benefit there is the love without the fear.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:14
verses.text: In both of these God Himself, by whose goodness and mercy it is that we are anything, has given us in the two Testaments a rule of discipline.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:15
verses.text: For though both are found in both Testaments, still fear is prominent in the Old, and love in the New; which the apostle calls bondage in the one, and liberty in the other.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:16
verses.text: Of the marvellous order and divine harmony of these Testaments it would take long to speak, and many pious and learned men have discoursed on it.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:17
verses.text: The theme demands many books to set it forth and explain it as far as is possible for man.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:18
verses.text: He, then, who loves his neighbor endeavors all he can to procure his safety in body and in soul, making the health of the mind the standard in his treatment of the body.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:19
verses.text: And as regards the mind, his endeavors are in this order, that he should first fear and then love God.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:20
verses.text: This is true excellence of conduct, and thus the knowledge of the truth is acquired which we are ever in the pursuit of.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:21
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:22
verses.text: The Manich aeans agree with me as regards the duty of loving God and our neighbor, but they deny that this is taught in the Old Testament.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:23
verses.text: How greatly they err in this is, I think, clearly shown by the passages quoted above on both these duties.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:24
verses.text: But, in a single word, and one which only stark madness can oppose, do they not see the unreasonableness of denying that these very two precepts which they commend are quoted by the Lord in the Gospel from the Old Testament, "Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind;" and the other, "Thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself?"  Or if they dare not deny this, from the light of truth being too strong for them, let them deny that these precepts are salutary; let them deny, if they can, that they teach the best morality; let them assert that it is not a duty to love God, or to love our neighbor; that all things do not issue in good to them that love God; that it is not true that the love of our neighbor worketh no ill (a two-fold regulation of human life which is most salutary and excellent).

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:25
verses.text: By such assertions they cut themselves off not only from Christians, but from mankind.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:26
verses.text: But if they dare not speak thus, but must confess the divinity of the precepts, why do they not desist from assailing and maligning with horrible profanity the books from which they are quoted?  58.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:27
verses.text: Will they say, as they often do, that although we find these precepts in the books, it does not follow that all is good that is found there? How to meet and refute this quibble I do not well see.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:28
verses.text: Shall I discuss the words of the Old Testament one by one, to prove to stubborn and ignorant men their perfect agreement with the New Testament? But when will this be done? When shall I have time, or they patience? What, then, is to be done? Shall I desert the cause, and leave them to escape detection in an opinion which, though false and impious, is hard to disprove? I will not.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 29:29
verses.text: God will Himself be at hand to aid me; nor will He suffer me in those straits to remain helpless or forsaken.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 30

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 30:1
verses.text: Chapter 29.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 30:2
verses.text: —Of the Authority of the Scriptures.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 30:3
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 30:4
verses.text: Attend, then, ye Manich aeans, if perchance there are some of you of whom your superstition has hold so as to allow you yet to escape.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 30:5
verses.text: Attend, I say, without obstinacy, without the desire to oppose, otherwise your decision will be fatal to yourselves.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 30:6
verses.text: No one can doubt, and you are not so lost to the truth as not to understand that if it is good, as all allow, to love God and our neighbor, whatever hangs on these two precepts cannot rightly be pronounced bad.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 30:7
verses.text: What it is that hangs on them it would be absurd to think of learning from me.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 30:8
verses.text: Hear Christ Himself; hear Christ, I say; hear the Wisdom of God: "On these two commandments," He says, "hang all the law and the prophets".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 30:9
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 30:10
verses.text: What can the most shameless obstinacy say to this? That these are not Christ's words? But they are written in the Gospel as His words.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 30:11
verses.text: That the writing is false? Is not this most profane blasphemy? Is it not most presumptuous to speak thus? Is it not most foolhardy? Is it not most criminal? The worshippers of idols, who hate even the name of Christ, never dared to speak thus against these Scriptures.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 30:12
verses.text: For the utter overthrow of all literature will follow, and there will be an end to all books handed down from the past, if what is supported by such a strong popular belief and established by the uniform testimony of so many men and so many times, is brought into such suspicion, that it is not allowed to have the credit and the authority of common history.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 30:13
verses.text: In fine, what can you quote from any writings of which I may not speak in this way if it is quoted against my opinion and my purpose?  61.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 30:14
verses.text: And is it not intolerable that they forbid us to believe a book widely known and placed now in the hands of all, while they insist on our believing the book which they quote? If any writing is to be suspected, what should be more so than one which has not merited notoriety, or which may be throughout a forgery, bearing a false name? If you force such a writing on me against my will, and make a display of authority to drive me into belief, shall I, when I have a writing which I see spread far and wide for a length of time, and sanctioned by the concordant testimony of churches scattered over all the world, degrade myself by doubting, and, worse degradation, by doubting at your suggestion? Even if you brought forward other readings, I should not receive them unless supported by general agreement; and this being the case, do you think that now, when you bring forward nothing to compare with the text except your own silly and inconsiderate statement, mankind are so unreasonable and so forsaken by divine Providence as to prefer to those Scriptures not others quoted by you in refutation, but merely your own words? You ought to bring forward another manuscript with the same contents, but incorrupt and more correct, with only the passage wanting which you charge with being spurious.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 30:15
verses.text: For example, if you hold that the Epistle of Paul to the Romans is spurious, you must bring forward another incorrupt, or rather another manuscript with the same epistle of the same apostle, free from error and corruption.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 30:16
verses.text: You say you will not, lest you be suspected of corrupting it.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 30:17
verses.text: This is your usual reply, and a true one.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 30:18
verses.text: Were you to do this, we should assuredly have this very suspicion; and all men of any sense would have it too.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 30:19
verses.text: See then what you are to think of your own authority; and consider whether it is right to believe your words against these Scriptures, when the simple fact that a manuscript is brought forward by you makes it dangerous to put faith in it.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:1
verses.text: Chapter 30.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:2
verses.text: —The Church Apostrophised as Teacher of All Wisdom.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:3
verses.text: Doctrine of the Catholic Church.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:4
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:5
verses.text: But why say more on this? For who but sees that men who dare to speak thus against the Christian Scriptures, though they may not be what they are suspected of being, are at least no Christians? For to Christians this rule of life is given, that we should love the Lord Our God with all the heart, with all the soul, and with all the mind, and our neighbor as ourselves; for on these two commandments hang all the law and the prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:6
verses.text: Rightly, then, Catholic Church, most true mother of Christians, dost thou not only teach that God alone, to find whom is the happiest life, must be worshipped in perfect purity and chastity, bringing in no creature as an object of adoration whom we should be required to serve; and from that incorrupt and inviolable eternity to which alone man should be made subject, in cleaving to which alone the rational soul escapes misery, excluding everything made, everything liable to change, everything under the power of time; without confounding what eternity, and truth, and peace itself keeps separate, or separating what a common majesty unites: but thou dost also contain love and charity to our neighbor in such a way, that for all kinds of diseases with which souls are for their sins afflicted, there is found with thee a medicine of prevailing efficacy.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:7
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:8
verses.text: Thy training and teaching are childlike for children, forcible for youths, peaceful for the aged, taking into account the age of the mind as well as of the body.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:9
verses.text: Thou subjectest women to their husbands in chaste and faithful obedience, not to gratify passion, but for the propagation of offspring,  and for domestic society.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:10
verses.text: Thou givest to men authority over their wives, not to mock the weaker sex, but in the laws of unfeigned love.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:11
verses.text: Thou dost subordinate children to their parents in a kind of free bondage, and dost set parents over their children in a godly rule.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:12
verses.text: Thou bindest brothers to brothers in a religious tie stronger and closer than that of blood.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:13
verses.text: Without violation of the connections of nature and of choice, thou bringest within the bond of mutual love every relationship of kindred, and every alliance of affinity.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:14
verses.text: Thou teachest servants to cleave to their masters from delight in their task rather than from the necessity of their position.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:15
verses.text: Thou renderest masters forbearing to their servants, from a regard to God their common Master, and more disposed to advise than to compel.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:16
verses.text: Thou unitest citizen to citizen, nation to nation, yea, man to man, from the recollection of their first parents, not only in society but in fraternity.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:17
verses.text: Thou teachest kings to seek the good of their peoples; thou counsellest peoples to be subject to their kings.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:18
verses.text: Thou teachest carefully to whom honor is due, to whom regard, to whom reverence, to whom fear, to whom consolation, to whom admonition, to whom encouragement, to whom discipline, to whom rebuke, to whom punishment; showing both how all are not due to all, and how to all love is due, and how injury is due to none.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:19
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:20
verses.text: Then, after this human love has nourished and invigorated the mind cleaving to thy breast, and fitted it for following God, when the divine majesty has begun to disclose itself as far as suffices for man while a dweller on the earth, such fervent charity is produced, and such a flame of divine love is kindled, that by the burning out of all vices, and by the purification and sanctification of the man, it becomes plain how divine are these words, "I am a consuming fire,"  and, "I have come to send fire on the earth".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:21
verses.text: These two utterances of one God stamped on both Testaments, exhibit with harmonious testimony, the sanctification of the soul, pointing forward to the accomplishment of that which is also quoted in the New Testament from the Old: "Death is swallowed up in victory.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:22
verses.text: O death, where is thy sting? Where, O death, is thy contest?"  Could these heretics understand this one saying, no longer proud but quite reconciled, they would worship God nowhere but with thee and in thy bosom.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:23
verses.text: In thee, as is fit, divine precepts are kept by widely-scattered multitudes.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:24
verses.text: In thee, as is fit, it is well understood how much more heinous sin is when the law is known than when it is unknown.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:25
verses.text: For "the sting of death is sin, and the strength of sin is the law,"  which adds to the force with which the consciousness of disregard of the precept strikes and slays.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:26
verses.text: In thee it is seen, as is fit, how vain is effort under the law, when lust lays waste the mind, and is held in check by fear of punishment, instead of being overborne by the love of virtue.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 31:27
verses.text: Thine, as is fit, are the many hospitable, the many friendly, the many compassionate, the many learned, the many chaste, the many saints, the many so ardent in their love to God, that in perfect continence and amazing indifference to this world they find happiness even in solitude.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:1
verses.text: Chapter 31.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:2
verses.text: —The Life of the Anachoretes and Coenobites Set Against the Continence of the Manich aeans.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:3
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:4
verses.text: What must we think is seen by those who can live without seeing their fellow-creatures, though not without loving them? It must be something transcending human things in contemplating which man can live without seeing his fellow-man.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:5
verses.text: Hear now, ye Manich aeans, the customs and notable continence of perfect Christians, who have thought it right not only to praise but also to practise the height of chastity, that you may be restrained, if there is any shame in you, from vaunting your abstinence before uninstructed minds as if it were the hardest of all things.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:6
verses.text: I will speak of things of which you are not ignorant, though you hide them from us.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:7
verses.text: For who does not know that there is a daily increasing multitude of Christian men of absolute continence spread all over the world, especially in the East and in Egypt, as you cannot help knowing?  66.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:8
verses.text: I will say nothing of those to whom I just now alluded, who, in complete seclusion from the view of men, inhabit regions utterly barren, content with simple bread, which is brought to them periodically, and with water, enjoying communion with God, to whom in purity of mind they cleave, and most blessed in contemplating His beauty, which can be seen only by the understanding of saints.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:9
verses.text: I will say nothing of them, because some people think them to have abandoned human things more than they ought, not considering how much those may benefit us in their minds by prayer, and in their lives by example, whose bodies we are not permitted to see.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:10
verses.text: But to discuss this point would take long, and would be fruitless; for if a man does not of his own accord regard this high pitch of sanctity as admirable and honorable, how can our speaking lead him to do so? Only the Manich aeans, who make a boast of nothing, should be reminded that the abstinence and continence of the great saints of the Catholic Church has gone so far, that some think it should be checked and recalled within the limits of humanity,—so far above men, even in the judgment of those who disapprove, have their minds soared.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:11
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:12
verses.text: But if this is beyond our tolerance, who can but admire and commend those who, slighting and discarding the pleasures of this world, living together in a most chaste and holy society, unite in passing their time in prayers, in readings, in discussions, without any swelling of pride, or noise of contention, or sullenness of envy; but quiet, modest, peaceful, their life is one of perfect harmony and devotion to God, an offering most acceptable to Him from whom the power to do those things is obtained? No one possesses anything of his own; no one is a burden to another.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:13
verses.text: They work with their hands in such occupations as may feed their bodies without distracting their minds from God.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:14
verses.text: The product of their toil they give to the decans or tithesmen,—so called from being set over the tithes,—so that no one is occupied with the care of his body, either in food or clothes, or in anything else required for daily use or for the common ailments.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:15
verses.text: These decans, again, arranging everything with great care, and meeting promptly the demands made by that life on account of bodily infirmities, have one called "father," to whom they give in their accounts.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:16
verses.text: These fathers are not only more saintly in their conduct, but also distinguished for divine learning, and of high character in every way; and without pride they superintend those whom they call their children, having themselves great authority in giving orders, and meeting with willing obedience from those under their charge.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:17
verses.text: At the close of the day they assemble from their separate dwellings before their meal to hear their father, assembling to the number of three thousand at least for one father; for one may have even a much larger number than this.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:18
verses.text: They listen with astonishing eagerness in perfect silence, and give expression to the feelings of their minds as moved by the words of the preacher, in groans, or tears, or signs of joy without noise or shouting.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:19
verses.text: Then there is refreshment for the body, as much as health and a sound condition of the body requires, every one checking unlawful appetite, so as not to go to excess even in the poor, inexpensive fare provided.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:20
verses.text: So they not only abstain from flesh and wine, in order to gain the mastery over their passions, but also from those things which are only the more likely to whet the appetite of the palate and of the stomach, from what some call their greater cleanness, which often serves as a ridiculous and disgraceful excuse for an unseemly taste for exquisite viands, as distant from animal food.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:21
verses.text: Whatever they possess in addition to what is required for their support (and much is obtained, owing to their industry and frugality), they distribute to the needy with greater care than they took in procuring it for themselves.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:22
verses.text: For while they make no effort to obtain abundance, they make every effort to prevent their abundance remaining with them,—so much so, that they send shiploads to places inhabited by poor people.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:23
verses.text: I need say no more on a matter known to all.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:24
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:25
verses.text: Such, too, is the life of the women, who serve God assiduously and chastely, living apart and removed as far as propriety demands from the men, to whom they are united only in pious affection and in imitation of virtue.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:26
verses.text: No young men are allowed access to them, nor even old men, however respectable and approved, except to the porch, in order to furnish necessary supplies.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:27
verses.text: For the women occupy and maintain themselves by working in wool, and hand over the cloth to the brethren, from whom, in return, they get what they need for food.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:28
verses.text: Such customs, such a life, such arrangements, such a system, I could not commend as it deserves, if I wished to commend it; besides, I am afraid that it would seem as if I thought it unlikely to gain acceptance from the mere description of it, if I considered myself obliged to add an ornamental eulogium to the simple narrative.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:29
verses.text: Ye Manich aeans, find fault here if you can.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 32:30
verses.text: Do not bring into prominence our tares before men too blind to discriminate.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 33

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 33:1
verses.text: Chapter 32.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 33:2
verses.text: —Praise of the Clergy.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 33:3
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 33:4
verses.text: There is not, however, such narrowness in the moral excellence of the Catholic Church as that I should limit my praise of it to the life of those here mentioned.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 33:5
verses.text: For how many bishops have I known most excellent and holy men, how many presbyters, how many deacons, and ministers of all kinds of the divine sacraments, whose virtue seems to me more admirable and more worthy of commendation on account of the greater difficulty of preserving it amidst the manifold varieties of men, and in this life of turmoil! For they preside over men needing cure as much as over those already cured.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 33:6
verses.text: The vices of the crowd must be borne with in order that they may be cured, and the plague must be endured before it is subdued.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 33:7
verses.text: To keep here the best way of life and a mind calm and peaceful is very hard.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 33:8
verses.text: Here, in a word, we are among people who are learning to live.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 33:9
verses.text: There they live.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:1
verses.text: Chapter 33.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:2
verses.text: —Another Kind of Men Living Together in Cities.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:3
verses.text: Fasts of Three Days.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:4
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:5
verses.text: Still I would not on this account cast a slight upon a praiseworthy class of Christians,—those, namely, who live together in cities, quite apart from common life.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:6
verses.text: I saw at Milan a lodging-house of saints, in number not a few, presided over by one presbyter, a man of great excellence and learning.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:7
verses.text: At Rome I knew several places where there was in each one eminent for weight of character, and prudence, and divine knowledge, presiding over all the rest who lived with him, in Christian charity, and sanctity, and liberty.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:8
verses.text: These, too, are not burdensome to any one; but, in the Eastern fashion, and on the authority of the Apostle Paul, they maintain themselves with their own hands.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:9
verses.text: I was told that many practised fasts of quite amazing severity, not merely taking only one meal daily towards night, which is everywhere quite common, but very often continuing for three days or more in succession without food or drink.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:10
verses.text: And this among not men only, but women, who also live together in great numbers as widows or virgins, gaining a livelihood by spinning and weaving, and presided over in each case by a woman of the greatest judgment and experience, skilled and accomplished not only in directing and forming moral conduct, but also in instructing the understanding.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:11
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:12
verses.text: With all this, no one is pressed to endure hardships for which he is unfit; nothing is imposed on any one against his will; nor is he condemned by the rest because he confesses himself too feeble to imitate them: for they bear in mind how strongly Scripture enjoins charity on all: they bear in mind "To the pure all things are pure,"  and "Not that which entereth into your mouth defileth you, but that which cometh out of it".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:13
verses.text: Accordingly, all their endeavors are concerned not about the rejection of kinds of food as polluted, but about the subjugation of inordinate desire and the maintenance of brotherly love.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:14
verses.text: They remember, "Meats for the belly, and the belly for meats; but God shall destroy both it and them;"  and again, "Neither if we eat shall we abound, nor if we refrain from eating shall we be in want;"  and, above all, this: "It is good, my brethren, not to eat flesh, nor drink wine, nor anything whereby thy brother is offended;" for this passage shows that love is the end to be aimed at in all these things.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:15
verses.text: "For one man," he says, "believes that he can eat all things: another, who is weak, eateth herbs.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:16
verses.text: He that eateth, let him not despise him that eateth not; and let not him that eateth not judge him that eateth: for God hath approved him.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:17
verses.text: Who art thou that thou shouldest judge another man's servant? To his own master he stands or fails; but he shall stand: for God is able to make him to stand".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:18
verses.text: And a little after: "He that eateth, to the Lord he eateth, and giveth God thanks; and he that eateth not, to the Lord he eateth not, and giveth God thanks".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:19
verses.text: And also in what follows: "So every one of us shall give account of himself to God.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:20
verses.text: Let us not, then, any more judge one another: but judge this rather, that ye place no stumbling-block, or cause of offence, in the way of a brother.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:21
verses.text: I know, and am confident in the Lord Jesus, that there is nothing common in itself: but to him that thinketh anything to be common, to him it is common".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:22
verses.text: Could he have shown better that it is not in the things we eat, but in the mind, that there is a power able to pollute it, and therefore that even those who are fit to think lightly of these things, and know perfectly that they are not polluted if they take any food in mental superiority, without being gluttons, should still have regard to charity? See what he adds: "For if thy brother be grieved with thy meat, now walkest thou not charitably".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:23
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:24
verses.text: Read the rest: it is too long to quote all.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:25
verses.text: You will find that those able to think lightly of such things,—that is, those of greater strength and stability,—are told that they must nevertheless abstain, lest those should be offended who from their weakness are still in need of such abstinence.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:26
verses.text: The people I was describing know and observe these things; for they are Christians, not heretics.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:27
verses.text: They understand Scripture according to the apostolic teaching, not according to the presumptuous and fictitious name of apostle.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:28
verses.text: Him that eats not no one despises; him that eats no one judges; he who is weak eats herbs.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:29
verses.text: Many who are strong, however, do this for the sake of the weak; with many the reason for so doing is not this, but that they may have a cheaper diet, and may lead a life of the greatest tranquillity, with the least expensive provision for the support of the body.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:30
verses.text: "For all things are lawful for me," he says; "but I will not be brought under the power of any".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:31
verses.text: Thus many do not eat flesh, and yet do not superstitiously regard it as unclean.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:32
verses.text: And so the same people who abstain when in health take it when unwell without any fear, if it is required as a cure.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:33
verses.text: Many drink no wine; but they do not think that wine defiles them; for they cause it to be given with the greatest propriety and moderation to people of languid temperament, and, in short, to all who cannot have bodily health without it.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:34
verses.text: When some foolishly refuse it, they counsel them as brothers not to let a silly superstition make them weaker instead of making them holier.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:35
verses.text: They read to them the apostle's precept to his disciple to "take a little wine for his many infirmities".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:36
verses.text: Then they diligently exercise piety; bodily exercise, they know, profiteth for a short time, as the same apostle says.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:37
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:38
verses.text: Those, then who are able, and they are without number, abstain both from flesh and from wine for two reasons: either for the weakness of their brethren, or for their own liberty.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:39
verses.text: Charity is principally attended to.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:40
verses.text: There is charity in their choice of diet, charity in their speech, charity in their dress, charity in their looks.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:41
verses.text: Charity is the point where they meet, and the plan by which they act.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:42
verses.text: To transgress against charity is thought criminal, like transgressing against God.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:43
verses.text: Whatever opposes this is attacked and expelled; whatever injures it is not allowed to continue for a single day.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 34:44
verses.text: They know that it has been so enjoined by Christ and the apostles; that without it all things are empty, with it all are fulfilled.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 35

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 35:1
verses.text: Chapter 34.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 35:2
verses.text: —The Church is Not to Be Blamed for the Conduct of Bad Christians, Worshippers of Tombs and Pictures.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 35:3
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 35:4
verses.text: Make objections against these, ye Manich aeans, if you can.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 35:5
verses.text: Look at these people, and speak of them reproachfully, if you dare, without falsehood.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 35:6
verses.text: Compare their fasts with your fasts, their chastity with yours; compare them to yourselves in dress, food, self-restraint, and, lastly, in charity.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 35:7
verses.text: Compare, which is most to the point, their precepts with yours.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 35:8
verses.text: Then you will see the difference between show and sincerity, between the right way and the wrong, between faith and imposture, between strength and inflatedness, between happiness and wretchedness, between unity and disunion; in short, between the sirens of superstition and the harbor of religion.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 35:9
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 35:10
verses.text: Do not summon against me professors of the Christian name, who neither know nor give evidence of the power of their profession.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 35:11
verses.text: Do not hunt up the numbers of ignorant people, who even in the true religion are superstitious, or are so given up to evil passions as to forget what they have promised to God.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 35:12
verses.text: I know that there are many worshippers of tombs and pictures.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 35:13
verses.text: I know that there are many who drink to great excess over the dead, and who, in the feasts which they make for corpses, bury themselves over the buried, and give to their gluttony and drunkenness the name of religion.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 35:14
verses.text: I know that there are many who in words have renounced this world, and yet desire to be burdened with all the weight of worldly things, and rejoice in such burdens.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 35:15
verses.text: Nor is it surprising that among so many multitudes you should find some by condemning whose life you may deceive the unwary and seduce them from Catholic safety; for in your small numbers you are at a loss when called on to show even one out of those whom you call the elect who keeps the precepts, which in your indefensible superstition you profess.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 35:16
verses.text: How silly those are, how impious, how mischievous, and to what extent they are neglected by most, nearly all of you, I have shown in another volume.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 35:17
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 35:18
verses.text: My advice to you now is this: that you should at least desist from slandering the Catholic Church, by declaiming against the conduct of men whom the Church herself condemns, seeking daily to correct them as wicked children.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 35:19
verses.text: Then, if any of them by good will and by the help of God are corrected, they regain by repentance what they had lost by sin.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 35:20
verses.text: Those, again, who with wicked will persist in their old vices, or even add to them others still worse, are indeed allowed to remain in the field of the Lord, and to grow along with the good seed; but the time for separating the tares will come.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 35:21
verses.text: Or if, from their having at least the Christian name, they are to be placed among the chaff rather than among thistles, there will also come One to purge the floor and to separate the chaff from the wheat, and to assign to each part (according to its desert) the due reward.

chapters.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:1
verses.text: Chapter 35.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:2
verses.text: —Marriage and Property Allowed to the Baptized by the Apostles.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:3
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:4
verses.text: Meanwhile, why do you rage? why does party spirit blind your eyes? Why do you entangle yourselves in a long defence of such great error? Seek for fruit in the field, seek for wheat in the floor: they will be found easily, and will present themselves to the inquirer.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:5
verses.text: Why do you look so exclusively at the dross? Why do you use the roughness of the hedge to scare away the inexperienced from the fatness of the garden? There is a proper entrance, though known to but a few; and by it men come in, though you disbelieve it, or do not wish to find it.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:6
verses.text: In the Catholic Church there are believers without number who do not use the world, and there are those who "use it," in the words of the apostle, "as not using it,"  as was proved in those times when Christians were forced to worship idols.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:7
verses.text: For then, how many wealthy men, how many peasant householders, how many merchants, how many military men, how many leading men in their own cities, and how many senators, people of both sexes, giving up all these empty and transitory things, though while they used them they were not bound down by them, endured death for the salutary faith and religion, and proved to unbelievers that instead of being possessed by all these things they really possessed them?  78.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:8
verses.text: Why do you reproach us by saying that men renewed in baptism ought no longer to beget children, or to possess fields, and houses, and money? Paul allows it.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:9
verses.text: For, as cannot be denied, he wrote to believers, after recounting many kinds of evil-doers who shall not possess the kingdom of God: "And such were you," he says: "but ye are washed, but ye are sanctified, but ye are justified in the name of the Lord Jesus Christ and by the Spirit of our God".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:10
verses.text: By the washed and sanctified, no one, assuredly, will venture to think any are meant but believers, and those who have renounced this world.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:11
verses.text: But, after showing to whom he writes, let us see whether he allows these things to them.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:12
verses.text: He goes on: "All things are lawful for me, but all things are not expedient: all things are lawful for me, but I will not be brought under the power of any.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:13
verses.text: Meat for the belly, and the belly for meats: but God will destroy both it and them.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:14
verses.text: Now the body is not for fornication, but for the Lord, and the Lord for the body.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:15
verses.text: But God raised up the Lord, and will raise us up also by His own power.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:16
verses.text: Know ye not that your bodies are the members of Christ? shall I then take the members of Christ, and make them the members of an harlot? God forbid.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:17
verses.text: Know ye not that he which is joined to an harlot is made one body? for the twain, saith He, shall be one flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:18
verses.text: But he that is joined to the Lord is one spirit.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:19
verses.text: Flee fornication.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:20
verses.text: Whatever sin a man doeth is without the body: but he that committeth fornication sinneth against his own body.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:21
verses.text: Know ye not that your members are the temple of the Holy Spirit which is in you, which ye have of God, and ye are not your own? For ye are bought with a great price: glorify God, and carry Him in your body".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:22
verses.text: "But of the things concerning which ye wrote to me: it is good for a man not to touch a woman.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:23
verses.text: Nevertheless, to avoid fornication, let every man have his own wife, and let every woman have her own husband.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:24
verses.text: Let the husband render unto the wife due benevolence: and likewise also the wife unto the husband.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:25
verses.text: The wife hath not power of her own body, but the husband: and likewise also the husband hath not power of his own body, but the wife.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:26
verses.text: Defraud ye not one the other, except it be with consent for a time, that ye may have leisure for prayer; and come together again, that Satan tempt you not for your incontinency.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:27
verses.text: But I speak this by permission, and not of commandment.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:28
verses.text: For I would that all men were even as I myself: but every man hath his proper gift of God, one after this manner, and another after that".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:29
Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:30
verses.text: Has the apostle, think you, both shown sufficiently to the strong what is highest, and permitted to the weaker what is next best? Not to touch a woman he shows is highest when he says, "I would that all men were even as I myself".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:31
verses.text: But next to this highest is conjugal chastity, that man may not be the prey of fornication.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:32
verses.text: Did he say that these people were not yet believers because they were married? Indeed, by this conjugal chastity he says that those who are united are sanctified by one another, if one of them is an unbeliever, and that their children also are sanctified.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:33
verses.text: "The unbelieving husband," he says, "is sanctified by the believing wife, and the unbelieving woman by the believing husband: otherwise your children would be unclean; but now are they holy".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:34
verses.text: Why do you persist in opposition to such plain truth? Why do you try to darken the light of Scripture by vain shadows?  80.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:35
verses.text: Do not say that catechumens are allowed to have wives, but not believers; that catechumens may have money, but not believers.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:36
verses.text: For there are many who use as not using.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:37
verses.text: And in that sacred washing the renewal of the new man is begun so as gradually to reach perfection, in some more quickly, in others more slowly.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:38
verses.text: The progress, however, to a new life is made in the case of many, if we view the matter without hostility, but attentively.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:39
verses.text: As the apostle says of himself, "Though the outward man perish, the inward man is renewed day by day".

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:40
verses.text: The apostle says that the inward man is renewed day by day that it may reach perfection; and you wish it to begin with perfection! And it were well if you did wish it.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:41
verses.text: In reality, you aim not at raising the weak, but at misleading the unwary.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:42
verses.text: You ought not to have spoken so arrogantly, even if it were known that you are perfect in your childish precepts.

verses.name: Augustine: Of the Morals of the Catholic Church 36:43
verses.text: But when your conscience knows that those whom you bring into your sect, when they come to a more intimate acquaintance with you, will find many things in you which nobody hearing you accuse others would suspect, is it not great impertinence to demand perfection in the weaker Catholics, to turn away the inexperienced from the Catholic Church, while you show nothing of the kind in yourself to those thus turned away? But not to seem to inveigh against you without reason, I will now close this volume, and will proceed at last to set forth the precepts of your life and your notable customs.
